conclusion: To express van der Waals constants a and b in terms of T_c and P_c, use van der Waals equation and conditions at critical point.
Van der Waals equation: (P + a/V^2)(V - b) = RT
At critical point, first derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
At critical point, second derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
Volume at critical point is denoted as V_c.
Van der Waals equation at critical point becomes: (P_c + a/V_c^2)(V_c - b) = RT_c
Differentiate van der Waals equation with respect to V: ∂P/∂V = -2a/V^3 + RT/(V - b)^2
Differentiate first derivative with respect to V: ∂^2P/∂V^2 = 6a/V^4 - 2RT/(V - b)^3
From first derivative condition: 2a/V_c^3 = RT_c/(V_c - b)^2
Divide second derivative equation by first derivative equation: 3/V_c = 1/(V_c - b)
Solve for b: 3(V_c - b) = V_c, b = 2V_c/3
Substitute b into first derivative condition: 2a/V_c^3 = RT_c/(V_c/3)^2
Express V_c in terms of P_c and T_c using van der Waals equation at critical point.
